subject: RE: [junit] Submitting a link to the JUnit page
msgSnippet: Thank you very much for the kind words Scott. We intended the book to work exactly as you describe--giving readers a guide to some useful tools, and thus
messageBody:
Thank you very much for the kind words Scott. We intended the book to work
exactly as you describe--giving readers a guide to some useful tools, and
thus giving them an incentive to start using said tools. Of course, most XP
developers already know JUnit and Ant. However, since they are the most
popular and general purpose, we thought they deserved coverage as well.

Cheers,

Nicholas Lesiecki
Technical Team Lead
eBlox, Inc.
(520) 615-9345 x104
Check out my new book!:
Java Tools for Extreme Programming: Mastering Open Source Tools, including
Ant, JUnit, and Cactus

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/047120708X/qid=1009555097/sr=8-1/ref=
sr_8_3_1/104-6010699-0942316


-----Original Message-----
From: Scott Stirling [mailto:sstirling@...]
Sent: Thursday, December 27, 2001 10:25 PM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com '
Subject: RE: [junit] Submitting a link to the JUnit page


I checked out this book at Borders today. It looks good. I am going to
recommend to the QA team and engineers at Macromedia.

I'm pretty well beyond the book's coverage on JUnit and Ant, so those
sections weren't of interest to me, but what was interesting was the
coverage of JMeter, JUnitPerf, HttpUnit, and Cactus. Sometimes it will be
much faster for folks to use a book like this to get up to speed on those
tools than if they were left to figure them our for themselves (which many
will never bother to even try).

The best thing about it just from browsing it for a few minutes was that I
learned that JMeter has grown up quite a bit since I last checked it out
over a year ago.

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia
